00042 static inline int u_equal(const void* s1, const void* s2, uint32_t n, bool ignore_case) /* Equal with ignore case */
00043 {
00044         U_INTERNAL_TRACE("u_equal(%p,%p,%u)", s1, s2, n)
00045 
00046         U_INTERNAL_ASSERT_MAJOR(n,0)
00047         U_INTERNAL_ASSERT_POINTER(s1)
00048         U_INTERNAL_ASSERT_POINTER(s2)
00049 
00050         return (ignore_case ? strncasecmp((const char*)s1, (const char*)s2, n)
00051                                                           :      memcmp(             s1,              s2, n));
00052 }

00068 /* WILDCARD PATTERN - The rules are as follows (POSIX.2, 3.13).
00069 
00070 Wildcard Matching
00071  A string is a wildcard pattern if it contains one of the characters '?', '*' or '['. Globbing is the operation that
00072  expands a wildcard pattern into the list of pathnames matching the pattern. Matching is defined by:
00073 
00074  A '?' (not between brackets) matches any single character.
00075  A '*' (not between brackets) matches any string, including the empty string.
00076 
00077 Character classes
00078  An expression '[...]' where the first character after the leading '[' is not an '!' matches a single character, namely
00079  any of the characters enclosed by the brackets. The string enclosed by the brackets cannot be empty; therefore ']' can
00080  be allowed between the brackets, provided that it is the first character. (Thus, '[][!]' matches the three characters
00081  '[', ']' and '!'.)
00082 
00083 Ranges
00084  There is one special convention: two characters separated by '-' denote a range. (Thus, '[A-Fa-f0-9]' is equivalent to
00085  '[ABCDEFabcdef0123456789]'.) One may include '-' in its literal meaning by making it the first or last character
00086  between the brackets. (Thus, '[]-]' matches just the two characters ']' and '-', and '[--0]' matches the three characters
00087  '-', '.', '0', since '/' cannot be matched.)
00088 
00089 Complementation
00090  An expression '[!...]' matches a single character, namely any character that is not matched by the expression obtained
00091  by removing the first '!' from it. (Thus, '[!]a-]' matches any single character except ']', 'a' and '-'.)
00092 
00093  One can remove the special meaning of '?', '*' and '[' by preceding them by a backslash, or, in case this is part of a
00094  shell command line, enclosing them in quotes. Between brackets these characters stand for themselves. Thus, '[[?*\]'
00095  matches the four characters '[', '?', '*' and '\'.
00096 
00097 Pathnames
00098  Globbing is applied on each of the components of a pathname separately. A '/' in a pathname cannot be matched by a '?'
00099  or '*'  wildcard, or by a range like '[.-0]'. A range cannot contain an explicit '/' character; this would lead to a
00100  syntax error.
00101 
00102  If a filename starts with a '.', this character must be matched explicitly. (Thus, 'rm *' will not remove .profile,
00103  and 'tar c *' will not archive all your files; 'tar c .' is better.)
00104 
00105 Note that wildcard patterns are not regular expressions, although they are a bit similar. First of all, they match
00106 filenames, rather than text, and secondly, the conventions are not the same: for example, in a regular expression '*'
00107 means zero or more copies of the preceding thing.
00108 
00109 Now that regular expressions have bracket expressions where the negation is indicated by a '^', POSIX has declared the
00110 effect of a wildcard pattern '[^...]' to be undefined.
00111 */
00112

00122 enum MatchType { U_FNMATCH = 0, U_DOSMATCH = 1, U_DOSMATCH_WITH_OR = 2 };

00124 static inline void u_setPfnMatch(int match_type, int flags)
00125 {
00126         U_INTERNAL_TRACE("u_setPfnMatch(%d,%d)", match_type, flags)
00127 
00128         u_pfn_flags = flags;
00129         u_pfn_match = (match_type == U_FNMATCH  ? u_fnmatch  :
00130                                                 match_type == U_DOSMATCH ? u_dosmatch : u_dosmatch_with_OR);
00131 }

00207 /* character type identification - Assumed an ISO-1 character set */
00208 
00209 extern U_EXPORT const unsigned char* u__ct_tab;
00210 extern U_EXPORT const unsigned char* u__ct_tol;
00211 extern U_EXPORT const unsigned char* u__ct_tou;
00212 
00213 static inline bool u_iscntrl(int c)  { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x01) != 0; } // __C } /* Control character. */
00214 static inline bool u_isdigit(int c)  { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x02) != 0; } // __D } /* Digit. */
00215 static inline bool u_islower(int c)  { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x04) != 0; } // __L } /* Lowercase. */
00216 static inline bool u_ispunct(int c)  { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x08) != 0; } // __P } /* Punctuation. */
00217 static inline bool u_isspace(int c)  { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x10) != 0; } // __S } /* Space. */
00218 static inline bool u_isupper(int c)  { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x20) != 0; } // __U } /* Uppercase. */
00219 static inline bool u_isblank(int c)  { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x80) != 0; } // __B } /* Blank. */
00220 
00221 static inline bool u_isalpha( int c) { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x24) != 0; } // (__L | __U)
00222 static inline bool u_isxdigit(int c) { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x42) != 0; } // (__D | __X)
00223 static inline bool u_isalnum( int c) { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x26) != 0; } // (__D | __L | __U)
00224 static inline bool u_isgraph( int c) { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x2E) != 0; } // (__D | __L | __P | __U)
00225 static inline bool u_isprint( int c) { return (u__ct_tab[c] & 0x3E) != 0; } // (__D | __L | __P | __S | __U)
00226 
00227 static inline int u_tolower(int c)       { return u__ct_tol[c]; }
00228 static inline int u_toupper(int c)       { return u__ct_tou[c]; }
00229 
00230 static inline bool u_isoctal( int c) { return ('0' <= c && c <= '7'); }
00231 static inline char u_octc2int(int c) { return ((c - '0') & 07); }
00232 static inline char u_hexc2int(int c) { return (u_isdigit(c) ? c - '0' : u_toupper(c) - 'A' + 10); }
00233 static inline bool u_isbase64(int c) { return (u_isalnum(c) || (c == '+') || (c == '/') || (c == '=')); }

00252 extern U_EXPORT bool u_isText( const unsigned char* s, uint32_t n);

00254 extern U_EXPORT int  u_isUTF16( const unsigned char* s, uint32_t n);
00255 static inline   bool u_isBinary(const unsigned char* s, uint32_t n) { return ((u_isText(s,n) || u_isUTF8(s,n) || u_isUTF16(s,n)) == false); }

00257 /* ip address type identification */
00258 
00259 static inline bool u_isIPv4Addr(const char* p, uint32_t n)
00260         { char c; uint32_t i = 0; for (; i < n; ++i) { c = p[i]; if (u_isdigit(c)  == 0 && c != '.')                                    return false; } return true; } 
00261 
00262 static inline bool u_isIPv6Addr(const char* p, uint32_t n)
00263         { char c; uint32_t i = 0; for (; i < n; ++i) { c = p[i]; if (u_isxdigit(c) == 0 && c != '.' && c != ':') return false; } return true; } 
00264 
00265 static inline bool u_isIPAddr(bool IPv6, const char* p, uint32_t n) { return (IPv6 ? u_isIPv6Addr(p, n) : u_isIPv4Addr(p, n)); }

00267 /* Quick and dirty int->hex. The only standard way is to call snprintf (?),
00268  * which is undesirably slow for such a frequently-called function... */
00269 
00270 static inline void u_int2hex(char* p, uint32_t n)
00271         { int s; for (s = 28; s >= 0; s -= 4, ++p) *p = u_hex_upper[(n >> s) & 0xf]; }
00272 
00273 static inline uint32_t u_hex2int(const char* p, uint32_t len)
00274         { uint32_t n = 0; const char* eos = p + len; while (p < eos) n = (n << 4) | u_hexc2int(*p++); return n; }

00276 #ifdef HAVE_SSL
00277 /*
00278 The u_passwd_cb() function must write the password into the provided buffer buf which is of size size.
00279 The actual length of the password must be returned to the calling function. rwflag indicates whether the
00280 callback is used for reading/decryption (rwflag=0) or writing/encryption (rwflag=1).
00281 See man SSL_CTX_set_default_passwd_cb(3) for more information
00282 */
00283 extern U_EXPORT int u_passwd_cb(char* buf, int size, int rwflag, void* password);
